description.plain:
Quincy Matthew Hanley (b. October 26, 1986), better known by the stage name ScHoolboy Q, is an American hip hop recording artist from South Central Los Angeles, California. Signed to Top Dawg Entertainment and Interscope Records, Hanley is a member of hip-hop supergroup Black Hippy, along with fellow West Coast rappers and label-mates Ab-Soul, Jay Rock, and Kendrick Lamar.

Q was born on October 26, 1989, in a military base in Germany. His parents separated and he and his mother moved to Texas for a short while. He later moved to LA with his mother, and he spent most of his time growing up there. In high school, he played a lot of sports, including baseball and football. He also joined the 52 Hoover Street Crips gang.

In an interview, he said his name comes from a local pimp in his neighborhood along with his academic standing in high school. He has a daughter named Joy.

Preceded by two mixtapes, his first independent album Setbacks, released January 11, 2011, reached #100 on the US Billboard 200 chart, selling close to 1,000 digital copies in the first week. Almost a year later on January 14, 2012, he released his second independent album Habits & Contradictions. The album debuted at #111 on the US Billboard 200, with first-week sales of 3,900 digital copies in the United States. His major label debut studio album, entitled Oxymoron, was released on February 25th, 2014 & received a 78 out of 100 on Metacritic. The album debuted at #1 on the US Billboard 200, with first-week sales of 139,000 copies. On July 8th, his sophomore major label studio album Blank Face LP was released and received an 81 out of 100 on Metacritic. The album debuted at # 2 on the Billboard 200.

The second single from Q’s highly anticipated album Oxymoron, on which the West Coast superstar recruits close personal friend and fellow Black Hippy member Kendrick Lamar to spit a bilingual verse.

In an interview, Schoolboy Q says that the meaning of Collard Greens is actually money.

songs.title: Studio

description.plain:
Not exactly what you would expect from a Hoover Crip now huh?

Oxymoron takes a rather unexpected twist with this love song. This is also reminiscent of labelmate Ab-Soul’s Empathy.

A little more than 6 months after Oxymoron dropped, an official remix featuring Nas was released via Soundcloud.

songs.full_title: Blessed by ScHoolboy Q (Ft. Kendrick Lamar)
songs.title: Blessed

description.plain:
ScHoolboy Q gets pretty emotional on a track dedicated to a friend of his who lost a son. This causes him to take a minute and realize how much good he has going for him, and urges us to do the same. Then Kendrick comes in and does his thing.

The beat is sampled from “Fall Into You” by Soulstice.

songs.full_title: THat Part by ScHoolboy Q (Ft. Kanye West)
songs.title: THat Part

description.plain:
“THat Part” is a braggadocious song influenced by Californian culture. The phrase “That part” is used as an affirmation of a boast.

ScHoolboy Q makes multiple references to his McLaren 12C in the first verse before referring to his drug dealing past later on in the song. Kanye West joins Q for their first collaboration, referencing the famous O.J. Simpson murder trial and Kobe Bryant’s final NBA game.

Q and Ye announced the song through slightly vague tweets, alluding to a meme line from Kendrick Lamar’s “Untitled 2”:

Get Top on the phone

https://twitter.com/ScHoolBoyQ/status/730782527833530369

The official music video was released June 2, 2016. The conclusion of the video displays the phone number 1-800-351-1132, possibly alluding to “getting Top on the phone.”.

The second single for Q’s new album, Blank Face, slated for release on July 8th 2016.

description.plain:
“THat Part” is a braggadocious song influenced by Californian culture. The phrase “That part” is used as an affirmation of a boast.

Black Hippy’s remix of ScHoolboy Q and Kanye West’s “THat Part” dropped as a surprise gift to the fans on July 7, 2016, minutes before the release of Blank Face LP.

Earlier on July 7, ScHoolboy Q was seen on his Snapchat hinting at the remix dropping. Top Dawg also teased the possibility of something big coming in the days leading up to the release of “THat Part (Black Hippy Remix).”

description.plain:
Track 2 from Schoolboy Q’s Habits and Contradictions, filled with plenty of high-pitched “there he go”’s!

Contains a sample of “Wet and Rusting” by Menomena and “One Man Band (Plays All Alone) by Monk Higgins

This would later be the inspiration for former Menomena bandmate Brent Knopf’s song with EL VY, “I’m The Man To Be”.

songs.full_title: Numb Numb Juice by ScHoolboy Q
songs.title: Numb Numb Juice

description.plain:
“Numb Numb Juice” is the lead single to ScHoolboy Q’s fifth studio album. The track first appeared on his Instagram with a 0:51 video clip of Q in the studio, after a series of hints on all of his social media platforms. The track was officially released on March 14, 2019, on all streaming services.

The menacing track finds Q returning to the rap game with his “coins up, bars up,” ready to hop out and shoot his opps like a “Jack-In-The-Box”—which serves as a metaphor, in that he is ready to kill it in the rap game as well.

The single was supported by a YouTube live premiere of the music video.

Producer DJ Fu talked about how the track came together:

This song is crazy because, originally, it was done by Sounwave, Baby Keem, and Cardo. Top [Dawg]’s son came to the studio like ‘Hey, Fu, can you build a new beat around this?’ I did it, and then Top and them loved it, but then Q’s like, ‘Nah, Fu, I know you can do better.’ So I came to the studio and we re-did the main melody and fixed it right there.

description.plain:
Essential reading before listening to this song

“Yay Yay” is ScHoolboy Q’s first single from his upcoming LP, “Oxymoron,” produced by Boi-1da and The Maven Boys. Q raps about growing up on Figg Street, similar to past songs like “Nightmare on Figg Street” and “Figg Get the Money.”

songs.full_title: The Purge by ScHoolboy Q (Ft. Kurupt & Tyler, The Creator)
songs.title: The Purge
songs.title_with_featured: The Purge (Ft. Kurupt & Tyler, The Creator)

description.plain:
Three representatives of West Coast Hip Hop over the years come together for a killer track off of ScHoolboy Q’s highly anticipated sophomore LP, Oxymoron.

Kurupt is from the origins of West Coast Hip Hop, and is well known for working with the likes of Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg.

ScHoolboy Q is a modern West Coast gangsta rapper, and is part of the supergroup Black Hippy with Kendrick Lamar, Ab Soul, and Jay Rock. The group has been called the modern N.W.A..

Tyler, the Creator is the frontman of the L.A. based collective Odd Future which is most famous for popularizing Alternative West Coast Hip Hop.

songs.full_title: Prescription / Oxymoron by ScHoolboy Q
songs.title: Prescription / Oxymoron

description.plain:
The two-part title track of Schoolboy’s major label debut deals with the consequences of doing the wrong thing for the right reasons. In Q’s case, he ended up getting addicted to prescription drugs that he was selling to make money and support his young daughter.

As confirmed by a tweet from Willie B, “Prescription” was produced by Sounwave, and “Oxymoron” by Willie B.

songs.full_title: JoHn Muir by ScHoolboy Q
songs.title: JoHn Muir

description.plain:
“JoHn Muir” is named after the John Muir Middle School which Q attended in during his adolescence in Los Angeles. On the track, he talks about participating in many illegal activities during his middle school years, such as having a gun at 13 and dealing dope at 14.

When Q previewed this track at his listening party, he said:

The beginning of me fucking with my homies from the hood. The beginning of me stealing, robbing, getting beat up, jackin’ niggas, getting jacked, the whole nine.

According to Q and Sounwave, the producer of the track, Q freestyled the entire song.

songs.full_title: By Any Means by ScHoolboy Q
songs.title: By Any Means

description.plain:
Initially premiered on June 24, 2016 as part of a 9 minute short film on his VEVO account, “By Any Means” is the third song released from Schoolboy Q’s Blank Face LP.

The title is an allusion to Malcolm X’s classic “By Any Means Necessary” speech, in which he argued that African Americans must seek:

 freedom by any means necessary… justice by any means necessary… [and] equality by any means necessary.

Q reinterprets Malcom X’s message to apply to the environment in which he grew up, one where any amount of violence, pimping, and drug running are justified in the name of “getting yours.”

songs.full_title: Tookie Knows II by ScHoolboy Q (Ft. TF & Traffic)
songs.title: Tookie Knows II

description.plain:
After hosting a listening party in NY, Q returned with a sequel to his “Tookie Knows” interlude from Habits & Contradictions. This song is also part two of Q’s video series, following the video to “By Any Means.”

In the song Q is joined by his childhood friends Traffic and TF on a heist that leads to a surreal prison rap session. The visuals seem to be heavily inspired by Vince Staples’s “Norf Norf” video, and Staples is also featured on this album.

Stanley “Tookie” Williams is the co-founder of the Crips gang in Los Angeles, CA.

songs.full_title: Hoover Street by ScHoolboy Q
songs.title: Hoover Street

description.plain:
Hoover Street is the quintessential time-travel song. On this song, Q is taking us back to his youth. This song details the various things Q experienced, witnessed and observed as a youth growing up on Hoover Street, such as his uncle stealing money out of his mother’s purse or the observation of how an addict with no money always finds someway to feed their habit. This is also a short chronicle of all the negativity Q was forced into upon joining the 52 Hoover Crips.



http://youtu.be/lmKGCH44ZHw

songs.full_title: Sacrilegious by ScHoolboy Q
songs.title: Sacrilegious

description.plain:
“Sacrilegious” is the sombre opening track of Schoolboy Q’s 2012 project, Habits & Contradictions. In this track, Q looks back at his life in the streets and gangbanging, finding regret in that he has done, things that God will never forgive him for.

Furthermore, the song samples “Nyt Pas” by the Danish group Suspekt.



The music video directed by Jerome D. was released on November 28, 2011.

songs.full_title: Overtime by ScHoolboy Q (Ft. Justine Skye & Miguel)
songs.title: Overtime

description.plain:
When ScHoolboy previewed his album in NYC on June 30th, he reportedly claimed his label Interscope forced him to make this song.

https://twitter.com/DJBooth/status/748333713533112320?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw

According to DJBooth:

Q went on to call the record a “bootleg ass” version of his 2014 song “Studio,” but he also admitted that the label was wise to help create and keep the track on the final version of the album despite his apprehensions about including a manufactured radio record on his album.

Skateboard P, the 2013 Producer of the Year, cooks up yet another banger here.



This song displays the more “Groovy” side of Q.

Q and Rock both describe their gang-banging lifestyle. Both rappers experienced the gang lifestyle, as Rock is a blood and Q is a crip—which can be seen as an oxymoron.

songs.full_title: Groovy Tony / Eddie Kane by ScHoolboy Q (Ft. Jadakiss)
songs.title: Groovy Tony / Eddie Kane

description.plain:
The fourth track off of Q’s fourth album, Blank Face LP. The first part, Groovy Tony, was the first single for the album. The album version features a verse from Jadakiss.

The music video for Groovy Tony was released on 4th April 2016.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7iJDXIOk0bg

Part II of the track, titled Eddie Kane is a reference to the character Eddie Kane from the musical – drama film  The Five Heartbeats,  directed and co – written by Robert Townsend. In the film, Eddie Kane was one of the lead singers in a Motown/Soul inspired group titled  The Five Heartbeats .



Eddie receives critical acclaim, wealth and fame with the group but eventually falls out by abusing drugs and battling inner demons. He later overcomes them.

In the first verse, Q draws parallels to Eddie’s downfall, but as a wealthy and successful dope dealer who is met with an unfortunate collapse as cops arrest him.

In the second verse, Q continues to draw parallels to Kane by painting a portrait of his life – talent and potential hindered by hardship. However, much like Kane, he overcomes his demons in the end.

The hook is performed much like how Kane sang in the movie – an illuminating, raspy voice that could fill an entire arena.

Groovy Tony can be seen as the unhinged, reckless thrill of his former life, while Eddie Kane shows its collapse and then rejuvenation, much like how the life of Eddie Kane is portrayed in the movie,  The Five Heartbeats. 

In short, while the character Eddie Cain/Kane, from  The Five Heartbeats   (Born Eddie King Jr.) was a cocaine addict, Groovy Tony sold it.

songs.full_title: Rolling Stone by ScHoolboy Q (Ft. Black Hippy)
songs.title: Rolling Stone

description.plain:
A Black Hippy posse cut included on ScHoolboy Q’s 2011 mixtape Setbacks. “Rolling Stone” uses a sample from “Time of the Season,” a song by The Zombies.



 The Zombies were a popular band during the 60’s and 70’s, and their lyrics in “Time of the Season” personify the entire Hippy era.

songs.full_title: CrasH by ScHoolboy Q
songs.title: CrasH

description.plain:
On “CrasH,” Q delivers a smooth flow over laid-back production from Boi-1da. Q discusses more serious topics of his life, including his family, wealth, and former life of crime. He recognizes that he must find a balance among all of the aspects of his life to overcome his unresolved issues and have some peace of mind.

“CrasH” is the third and final pre-release single from CrasH Talk.

Q enlists Vince Staples for this bass-heavy banger that paints a solid picture of what gang life is like in their respective hoods. The two trade bars over dense, groovy Sounwave production.



They previously collaborated on 2013’s “Back Sellin' Crack”.

songs.full_title: Fuck LA by ScHoolboy Q
songs.title: Fuck LA

description.plain:
A deluxe bonus track produced by Nez & Rio the production duo which also produced the tracks: “Gangsta,” “Man of the Year” and “Californication” from the same album.

During the song Q speaks of his past lifestyle as a 52 Hoover crip gang member and that gangsta rap is slowly dying, he’s continuing the tradition of keeping West Coast rap alive.

On an interview with Noisey Raps he says:

songs.full_title: Groovy Tony by ScHoolboy Q
songs.title: Groovy Tony

description.plain:
“Groovy Tony” sees ScHoolboy Q compare himself to Tony Montana, a fictional drug lord and the protagonist of the 1983 film Scarface.  The character has a long history in hip-hop: Biggie’s “Ten Crack Commandments,” Jay Z’s “Can’t Knock The Hustle,” and Nas’s “The World Is Yours” make reference to Montana. Like Tony and these legendary MC’s, Q also dabbles in women, drugs and money.

The first single from his upcoming album, the song garnered a reasonable level of hype leading up to its release. Top Dawg’s founder Anthony “Top Dawg” Tiffith helped promote the track by posting a pre-release snippet of the song on Instagram, as well as teasing the idea of dropping a new song after his flight.

https://twitter.com/dangerookipawaa/status/717085840913014784?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw

“Groovy Tony” was released six hours later.

songs.full_title: His & Her Fiend by ScHoolboy Q (Ft. Lance Skiiiwalker & SZA)
songs.title: His & Her Fiend
songs.title_with_featured: His & Her Fiend (Ft. Lance Skiiiwalker & SZA)

description.plain:
In this song Q is rapping as an Oxycontin pill who is everyone’s friend, and SZA is the pill user. Contrary to what iTunes or Spotify may tell you, Q named this song “His & Her Fiend”, as shown by his physical album and his NPR promotional interview:

Man, I was amazed. When I did my last song — the last song I did was “His and Her Fiend,” where I’m talking as the oxy pill and she’s talking as the fiend…[referring to the emptiness of the song] Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. You doped up. When you doped up, you blank out…“Can I show you this world, baby?” Like I told you, the dude was the devil, that gave me that pill. I was the devil in Seattle when I was giving — selling — people those pills. I was the devil.

songs.full_title: Grooveline Pt. 2 by ScHoolboy Q (Ft. Suga Free & SZA)
songs.title: Grooveline Pt. 2

description.plain:
In this song, Q and West Coast heavyweight Suga Free are rapping as pimps. This song is a sequel to “Grooveline Pt. 1” from ScHoolboy Q’s previous album, Habits & Contradictions.

Q explains the meaning behind writing this song in a promotional NPR interview:

Oxymoron though is more so — I done had my Setbacks, you get what I’m saying? These are the reasons. I was addicted to prescription drugs. I was a gang member. My grandma, she was — as much love as she showed me, she still was a bad influence on me at the same point also. I was around crackhead addicts. I was around pimps, hookers, prostitution. So you’ve got songs with me with Suga Free where I’m saying, “Will you sell that p—— for me?” I never been a pimp, but my block Figueroa that I always scream out “Figg side,” it’s big — if you was to think about Detroit or wherever pimps — or Frisco, you know what I’m saying? My name comes from a pimp named Schoolboy, from my block.

additional vocals by SZA

Water is used on this song to imply that the jewelry and material possessions they own are dripping and are very expensive.

songs.full_title: Str8 Ballin by ScHoolboy Q (Ft. Jesse Rankins)
songs.title: Str8 Ballin

description.plain: This song is an homage to the classic Thug Life song from Thug Life. It also makes reference to another 2Pac song, “Picture Me Rolling,” from All Eyez on Me. This song details Q’s rise from hustling every day to rapping for a living. Q contrasts his old life to his new life with a series of competitive verses. The song also touches on Q’s own self doubt growing up a poor black American.
